message_1: A particle is moving with a velocity of 0.8c in the x-direction. At t=0, it passes through the origin (x=y=z=0). Determine the equation for the trajectory of the particle as seen by a stationary observer.
message_2:
Since the particle is moving with a constant velocity of 0.8c in the x-direction, its trajectory will be a straight line along the x-axis. The position of the particle at any time t can be determined using the equation:

x(t) = x0 + v*t

where x0 is the initial position of the particle (which is 0 in this case), v is the velocity of the particle (0.8c), and t is the time.

So, the equation for the trajectory of the particle as seen by a stationary observer is:

x(t) = 0 + (0.8c)*t
x(t) = 0.8c*t

Since the particle is only moving in the x-direction, its y and z coordinates will remain constant at 0:

y(t) = 0
z(t) = 0

Thus, the trajectory of the particle as seen by a stationary observer is given by:

x(t) = 0.8c*t, y(t) = 0, z(t) = 0
